citation-title.titletext: Narratives and Practices of Migrant and Minority Incorporation in European Societies: Contested Diversity and Fractured Belongings

affiliation.organization: Doctor of Sociology and Senior Researcher/Lecturer at Universitat Pompeu Fabra,
affiliation.ce:source-text: Zenia Hellgren is Doctor of Sociology and Senior Researcher/Lecturer at Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona. Her research interests involve discriminations, intersectional inequalities and struggles over inclusion in the contexts of migration and diversity. She has published extensively in such leading journals as International Political Sociology, Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies, Ethnic and Racial Studies, and International Migration Review.

affiliation.organization: Associate Professor of Social Work specialising in migration, integration and diversity at the Norwegian University
affiliation.ce:source-text: Alexander Gamst Page is Associate Professor of Social Work specialising in migration, integration and diversity at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology, Norway.

affiliation.organization: Lecturer in Ethnicity and Race in the School of Sociology
affiliation.ce:source-text: Thomas Sealy is Lecturer in Ethnicity and Race in the School of Sociology, Politics and International Studies at the University of Bristol, UK.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: This book explores the disjuncture that emerges at various levels in European diversity management policies and their translation into practice. It shows that state-wide strategies can only guide diversification outcomes, not wholly control them, and in practice, national level integration policies rely on multi-level involvement including authorities at regional or local levels and civil society organisations. The book demonstrates a complex and varied picture of the ways in which different European countries engage with ethnic diversity, as well as to the internal (in)consistency of the philosophical underpinnings of this engagement. As such, it draws attention not just to ways in which diversity "is done," but illuminates processes and narratives which are messy, contested, and contradictory. This book is of key interest to scholars, students, and practitioners involved in integration, ethnic and cultural diversity studies, migration and immigration, citizenship, ethnicity, and more broadly to European studies, and the wider social sciences.

citation-title.titletext: Narratives and Practices of Migrant and Minority Incorporation in European Societies

affiliation.organization: Zenia Hellgren is Doctor of Sociology and Senior Researcher/Lecturer at Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona.
affiliation.ce:source-text: Zenia Hellgren is Doctor of Sociology and Senior Researcher/Lecturer at Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona. Her research interests involve discriminations, intersectional inequalities and struggles over inclusion in the contexts of migration and diversity. She has published extensively in such leading journals as International Political Sociology, Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies, Ethnic and Racial Studies, and International Migration Review.

affiliation.organization: Alexander Gamst Page is Associate Professor of Social Work at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology.
affiliation.ce:source-text: Alexander Gamst Page is Associate Professor of Social Work at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology. He has an MA in social anthropology and a PhD in social work focusing on migration, integration, and diversity. In addition to these topics, his research interests include religion, culture, discrimination and Islamophobia.

affiliation.organization: Thomas Sealy is Lecturer in Ethnicity and Race in the School of Sociology, Politics and International Studies at the University of Bristol.
affiliation.ce:source-text: Thomas Sealy is Lecturer in Ethnicity and Race in the School of Sociology, Politics and International Studies at the University of Bristol. He researches and teaches on religion and politics, multiculturalism, and ethnicity and racism. His books include The New Governance of Religious Diversity (2024), The Resilience of Multiculturalism: Ideas, Politics, Practice (2024, editor) and Post-Multiculturalism, Religion and Recognition (forthcoming).

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: It is hardly an exaggeration to describe our times as marked by growing political polarisation. This development is strongly felt in the policy field of integration and diversity management. Across Europe, neo-assimilationist and even outright xenophobic discourses are gaining presence and influence over immigration and integration policies, particularly at the state level, while particularly at the municipal level there is oftentimes firm commitment to diversity-positive agendas such as multiculturalism and interculturalism. However, also in contexts that officially promote diversity, tensions emerge around how to translate (pro-diversity) policies into more inclusive practices. In this introductory chapter we lay out the conceptual framework for the book. We map and contrast different policy approaches to integration and ethnic diversity in order to define the current European landscape of conflicting, or complementary, diversity management paradigms, and their implications for inclusion and belonging.

citation-title.titletext: Individualised Integration and Contractual Civic Integration Policies: A Dutch Case Study

affiliation.organization: Tamar de Waal is Associate Professor of Legal Philosophy and Citizenship
affiliation.ce:source-text: Tamar de Waal is Associate Professor of Legal Philosophy and Citizenship and serves as the Director of the Amsterdam Honours College of Law at the Amsterdam Law School, University of Amsterdam. She is the author of the book Integration Requirements for Immigrants in Europe: A Legal-Philosophical Inquiry.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: In a Europe where diversity politics are becoming notably stricter, there is an ongoing shift towards an “individualised” integration where the responsibility for successful outcomes is increasingly placed on the migrant. This chapter asks why the Dutch civic integration policy has had almost exclusively negative evaluations, arguing that this stems from the “contractual” ideology that increasingly underpins Dutch integration. This has led to interactional approaches where migrants are expected to “deliver” their individual integration in exchange for rights. Such contractual civic integration policies, on the one hand, do not lead to policy approaches where newcomers’ personal circumstances, ambitions and health are taken into account. On the other hand, contractual civic integration policies aiming to measure “deservingness to belong” also tend to clash with certain desirable societal outcomes. Instead of being installed and adjusted based on empirical research measuring whether they actually support emancipatory results, these policies are frequently amended based on (arbitrary) benchmarks of when individual newcomers are deemed to have integrated “enough.” The main conclusion of the chapter is that to fundamentally improve the policy outcomes of civic integration policies, legislators and policy-makers should recognise the ramifications of the shift towards individualised integration in order to reverse it.

citation-title.titletext: Challenges to National Frameworks of Minority Integration in Western Europe :Minority Accommodation, Transnationalism and Dual Citizenship

affiliation.organization: Erdem Dikici is Senior Lecturer at the School of Health and Social Wellbeing, the University of the West of England.
affiliation.ce:source-text: Erdem Dikici is Senior Lecturer at the School of Health and Social Wellbeing, the University of the West of England. His publications include Transnational Islam and the Integration of Turks in Great Britain (2021), “Integration, Transnationalism and Transnational Islam” (2022), and “Nationalism Is Dead, Long Live Nationalism!” (2022).

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: The accommodation of post-war ethno-cultural and ethno-religious communities has been exclusively framed within the boundaries of nation-states. National frameworks of diversity governance across Western Europe often overlook mobilities and transnational engagements of minorities, as well as transnational state and non-state actors. This chapter argues that nation-state-centric conceptual and policy approaches are challenged not only by the prevailing sociological condition but also by the mounting mobility and transnationalism studies. To address these challenges as well as to study post-war minority accommodation in contemporary Western Europe, this chapter proposes to reconsider minority integration as a three-way process and negotiation. This approach takes both national and transnational contexts and actors into account, proposing a rethinking of nation-state-centric frameworks of diversity governance through avoiding both methodological nationalism and methodological transnationalism. This chapter examines dual citizenship practices, emerging at the intersection of national regimes of citizenship and increased mobility, but are often discouraged citing a perceived splitting of loyalties. Applied in dual citizenship cases, the three-way approach demonstrates that minority integration and transnationalism are not necessarily mutually exclusive; dual citizenship does not simply consolidate mobility and transnational engagements and belongings but also reinforces accommodation into the country of residence.

citation-title.titletext: Multiculturalism and Interculturalism :Views from the Local

affiliation.organization: Thomas Sealy is Lecturer in Ethnicity and Race in the School of Sociology,
affiliation.ce:source-text: Thomas Sealy is Lecturer in Ethnicity and Race in the School of Sociology, Politics and International Studies at the University of Bristol. He researches and teaches on religion and politics, multiculturalism, and ethnicity and racism. His books include The New Governance of Religious Diversity (2024), The Resilience of Multiculturalism: Ideas, Politics, Practice (2024, editor) and Post-Multiculturalism, Religion and Recognition (forthcoming).

affiliation.organization: Pier-Luc Dupont is Lecturer in Identity Politics and Director of Comparative Politics
affiliation.ce:source-text: Pier-Luc Dupont is Lecturer in Identity Politics and Director of Comparative Politics and Policy Research Centre at Swansea University. He is an interdisciplinary scholar of racism, diversity and human rights, with a particular interest in employment and education as social and political fields. His work has been published in leading journals including Ethnic and Racial Studies, Identities, and Peace and Conflict.

affiliation.organization: Tariq Modood is Professor of Sociology, Politics and Public Policy and founding Director of the Centre for the Study of Ethnicity
affiliation.ce:source-text: Tariq Modood is Professor of Sociology, Politics and Public Policy and founding Director of the Centre for the Study of Ethnicity and Citizenship at the University of Bristol and Fellow of the British Academy. Modood’s latest publications include Essays on Secularism and Multiculturalism (2019) and The New Governance of Religious Diversity (2024). His website is tariqmodood.com.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: In the UK, as elsewhere in Europe, integration and social cohesion in relation to ethnic and cultural diversity are never far from the newspaper headlines or policy concerns. While these issues have gained attention from a variety of scholarly positions, one key debate has been between two pro-diversity paradigms of governance: multiculturalism (MC) and interculturalism (IC). Debates between the two camps have centred around the contention that IC can, should, or even has replaced MC as the dominant paradigm. Nevertheless, some research has begun to suggest that the two approaches live side by side in policy and can be complementary rather than antagonistic. This chapter addresses the matter of complementarity between MC and IC by focusing on the question of levels, in particular the relationship between the national and the local. To do so, it analyses two local policy documents to assess how they embody aspects of IC and MC, how they relate to one another, and with what emphases and rationales. This serves as the basis for assessing the question of complementarity.

citation-title.titletext: The Absence of Race in the Intercultural Narrative :An Anti-Racist Gaze at the Catalan Education System

affiliation.organization: Zenia Hellgren is Doctor of Sociology and Senior Researcher/Lecturer at Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona.
affiliation.ce:source-text: Zenia Hellgren is Doctor of Sociology and Senior Researcher/Lecturer at Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona. Her research interests involve discriminations, intersectional inequalities and struggles over inclusion in the contexts of migration and diversity. She has published extensively in such leading journals as International Political Sociology, Journal of Ethnic and Migration Studies, Ethnic and Racial Studies, and International Migration Review.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: In a European landscape where immigration and integration policies are increasingly influenced by far-right, xenophobic agendas, Catalonia remains committed to its intercultural approach. This is reflected in diversity policies that emphasise social cohesion and equality in a framework of ethnic, religious and cultural pluralism. Simultaneously, the inequalities affecting migrants and racialised minorities in Catalonia are huge, as elsewhere in Spain, and recent studies show that racism grows alarmingly. Nevertheless, there has long been reluctance to explicitly integrate anti-racism in the intercultural agenda. This chapter uses extensive fieldwork conducted between 2017 and 2024 in the frameworks of three different research projects. It engages with the apparent paradox that serious problems with “ethnic inequalities,” racism and discrimination are widespread also in an explicitly pro-diversity policy framework. Taking the case of the pronouncedly intercultural Catalan education system, I argue that the intercultural narrative, in its endeavour to avoid controversies and bring the vast majority of society on board, fails to efficiently address systemic racism and structural inequalities. Therefore, its desired transformative impact becomes harder to achieve and structures of “white preference” remain largely unchallenged.

citation-title.titletext: Paradoxes of Multiculturalism in Retrospect and Prospect :Remodelling Sweden

affiliation.organization: Aleksandra Ålund has a PhD in Sociology. She is Professor Emerita at REMESO, The Institute for Research on Migration,
affiliation.ce:source-text: Aleksandra Ålund has a PhD in Sociology. She is Professor Emerita at REMESO, The Institute for Research on Migration, Ethnicity and Society at Linköping University, Sweden. Her research is on social exclusion/inclusion, education, welfare and working life, education, gender, social movements, new ethnicities, cultural production, racism, and urban segregation.

affiliation.organization: Carl-Ulrik Schierup holds PhDs in Social Anthropology and Sociology. He is founder and was Director of the REMESO Institute for Research on Migration,
affiliation.ce:source-text: Carl-Ulrik Schierup holds PhDs in Social Anthropology and Sociology. He is founder and was Director of the REMESO Institute for Research on Migration, Ethnicity and Society at Linköping University, Sweden (2008–2017), where he is engaged as professor emeritus. His research is on racial capitalism, migration, labour and citizenship, and social movements.

affiliation.organization: Magnus Dahlstedt is Professor of Social Work at Linköping University, Sweden.
affiliation.ce:source-text: Magnus Dahlstedt is Professor of Social Work at Linköping University, Sweden. His research concerns the formation of citizenship in times of migration, welfare, and social policy transformations. A particular focus is put on mechanisms of inclusion/exclusion and the living conditions of young people in the context of a polarised urban landscape.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: The point of departure for this chapter is our book Paradoxes of Multiculturalism published in 1991. The book’s sharp critique of the disparity between political declarations and practice, exposing an ongoing racialisation of the Swedish welfare model, is as relevant today as it was at the time. In this framework, this chapter reviews three decades of social transformation in Sweden. What has unfolded since then is a gradual erosion of the welfare state, increasing austerity of migration, social and labour market policies, accompanied by stigmatisation of migrants and post-migrants. The chapter winds up discussing the emergence of a transversal movement for social justice initiated by a post-migrant generation in Sweden’s disadvantaged suburban neighbourhoods.

citation-title.titletext: A Folk Psychological Analysis of Migration-Related Narratives in Bulgaria :Who Gets to Belong?

affiliation.organization: Leda Kuneva is Research and Project Manager at Clever Together Democratie (France),
affiliation.ce:source-text: Leda Kuneva is Research and Project Manager at Clever Together Democratie (France), holding an MSc in Human Rights from the London School of Economics and Political Science. Her research addresses gender and intersectionality, knowledge, power and politics, and digital ethics. She is part of the United Nations Network on Migration.

affiliation.organization: Maria Stoyanova is Analyst at the Center for the Study of Democracy
affiliation.ce:source-text: Maria Stoyanova is Analyst at the Center for the Study of Democracy and a PhD candidate in European Political Science at Sofia University “St. Kliment Ohridski.” Her research focuses on the role of media in criminal justice, media freedom and online hatred and malign activities in the digital environment.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: Migration-related narratives are diverse, heterogeneous, and dynamic, being continuously communicated, presented as “true,” formed, and reformed by a multitude of actors. This chapter dives into the tangle of national-level narratives in Bulgaria, studying the varied and contentious voices in the public digital space concerning migrants from the so-called “Global South” and from Ukraine in relation to belonging, ex-/inclusion, discrimination, hostility/comradery, and the division between “us” and “the others.” Against the background of the wider sociopolitical environment in Bulgaria and our previous work in this field, we implement an online and social media observation (comments), seeking an answer to the question “Who gets to belong?” We examine migration-related narratives’ meanings, the sentiments expressed, and their (potential) change over time. All of this is viewed alongside Bulgarian folk psychology (national mentality/identity), to establish links between the formation of public-space narratives, on the one hand, and culture, xenophobic and anti-diversity political discourses, nationalism/traditionalism, and perceptions of self on the other. This complex relationship is embedded into the way Bulgarian society perceives the integration of migrants and diversity policies at the national level. These tensions of identity and belonging thus give rise to a significant social challenge for the implementation of inclusivity and integration.

citation-title.titletext: Transethnic Migrant Activism and Commoning in Trondheim

affiliation.organization: Agata Kochaniewicz is a PhD candidate at the Department of Social Anthropology, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU)
affiliation.ce:source-text: Agata Kochaniewicz is a PhD candidate at the Department of Social Anthropology, Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), and a member of the research group Temporalities of Mobility and Migration (NTNU) and the Center for Migration Studies at Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań. Her main anthropological interests are mobility studies, migration and feminist theory.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: In Norway, policies and public debates on minorities are mostly discussed in terms of integration, often meaning cultural and social assimilation (“becoming Norwegian”). This has been characterised by an individualised approach, with a strong focus on integration as the individual immigrant’s responsibility and the voluntary sector as a key actor in facilitating integration. Recently, we observe minority voices increasingly participating in the public sphere, developing embodied and grassroots knowledge creation, and resisting this racialised logic of inclusion and exclusion. This chapter describes transethnic migrant activism – in public spaces, online, and within public institutions – where migrants question structural inequalities and create new spaces of belonging. The local grassroots projects were started by Trondheim residents from different ethnic, racial, educational, and gender backgrounds to address issues of (un)belonging, multiculturalism, (mis)representation, and racism that they have experienced locally. The chapter analyses (im)possibilities for migrants to create counterpublics, transform institutional spaces, challenge exclusions, and reimagine narrations about Norwegianness at the micro level. The chapter is informed by ethnographic research conducted in Trondheim between 2019 and 2021. In terms of methodology, it is a combination of participant observation, semi-structured interviews, and activist research, as the author was one of the co-organisers of the project.

citation-title.titletext: The Instrumental Use of Incorporation Philosophies in a Multicultural Norway :Becoming Norwegian or Running in Place?

affiliation.organization: Alexander Gamst Page is Associate Professor of Social Work at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology.
affiliation.ce:source-text: Alexander Gamst Page is Associate Professor of Social Work at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology. He has an MA in social anthropology and a PhD in social work focusing on migration, integration, and diversity. In addition to these topics, his research interests include religion, culture, discrimination and Islamophobia.

affiliation.organization: Sobh Chahboun is Professor of Special Pedagogy at Queen Maud University College of Early Childhood Education
affiliation.ce:source-text: Sobh Chahboun is Professor of Special Pedagogy at Queen Maud University College of Early Childhood Education. She has degrees in psychology, linguistics, teaching and speech therapy. Her research interests include autism, language, and language development. She also heads research projects aimed at the experiences of Muslim migrants in Norway.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: This chapter is based on 20 interviews with volunteer-run organisations working on the incorporation, that is the integration and inclusion, of Norwegian Muslims. The participating organisations differ from each other in that some are specifically Muslim, balancing incorporation with the maintenance of religious and cultural identities. Others are non-Muslim, typically placing more emphasis on the social inclusion of the individual. However, both groups of participants present themselves in opposition to prominent right-wing voices, the spectre of which hangs over the interviews. Right-wing pundits are constantly quoted as counterexamples to the participants’ positions. Thus, we get three analytical entities, two being participants of this study, the third, a constructed “other” acting as a dramatic foil to both. This tripartite division creates interesting similarities and oppositions. The difference most central to the philosophy of the Muslim organisations is related to the debate on whether Islam is compatible with Norwegian values, and thus whether a multicultural integration framed around the retention of Muslim identity is an oxymoron. Possibly to sidestep this imbroglio, the Muslim participants downplay culture or values as a measure of integration, framing the incorporation of their members according to practical criteria, such as obeying the law, employment, and neighbourliness.

citation-title.titletext: Undocumented Unaccompanied Migrant Youth from Afghanistan in Sweden :Belonging as the Right to Exist

affiliation.organization: Mehrdad Darvishpour holds a PhD in Sociology and is Senior Lecturer and Associate Professor in Social Work at Mälardalens University in Sweden.
affiliation.ce:source-text: Mehrdad Darvishpour holds a PhD in Sociology and is Senior Lecturer and Associate Professor in Social Work at Mälardalens University in Sweden. Darvishpour has published several books and articles on immigrant women, gender issues, masculinity, honour-related violence, unaccompanied youth, ethnicity, discrimination, and integration. Darvishpour’s latest publication is Securitisation of the Swedish Migration Policy and the Situation for Unaccompanied Youth (2023).

affiliation.organization: Nicole Nunez Borgman has a Degree of Bachelor of Science in Social Work from Malmö University
affiliation.ce:source-text: Nicole Nunez Borgman has a Degree of Bachelor of Science in Social Work from Malmö University and a Master’s Degree in Child and Youth Studies from Stockholm University. Her work focuses on children in migration.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Zenia Hellgren, Alexander Gamst Page, and Thomas Sealy; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: In this chapter, we examine how belonging may be a contentious concept by addressing a phenomenon that calls into question its basic meaning: undocumented migration. We focus on the case of Sweden, where current asylum and migration policy restrictions further limit the already scarce possibilities that undocumented migrants, most of whom are asylum seekers who were not granted asylum, have to get by here. Our study of young undocumented unaccompanied migrants from Afghanistan explores the tensions between migration and border policies on the one hand, and other policy areas including social services, human rights, and children’s rights on the other hand. It illustrates how Swedish refugee policy restrictions and increasingly negative attitudes against immigrants strongly affect the wellbeing of undocumented young migrants, who live in situations of extreme vulnerability. The life situations of these young migrants reflect a particularly sensitive issue in relation to questions of belonging – the right to stay in a country, to some extent even to exist as a human being.
